facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 243, 344 and 345 of 1959 were heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: civil Appeals Nos. 243, 344 and 45 of 59.

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated January 12, 1950 of the Madras High Court in A.A.O. Nos. 288 to 290 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated January 12, 195O of the Madras High Court in A. A. O. Nos. 288 to 290 of 1946.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on September 4, 1962 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court disposed of Civil Appeals Nos. 343 and 344 of 1959 before addressing Civil Appeal No. 345 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: After disposing of Civil Appeals Nos. 343 and 344 of 1959, his Lordship proceeded as follows.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 345 of 1959, appellant sought liberty to proceed against sureties, respondents Nos. 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to Civil Appeal No. 345 of 1959 in which the appellant wants liberty to proceed against the surety, respondents Nos. 2 and 3.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's claim against sureties on basis that appellant was a defaulter.

anchor.surface_text: This claim has been rejected by both the High Court. But the decision of the High Court proceeds on the basis that the appellant was himself a defaulter

facts.text: Supreme Court held contrary conclusion that appellant was not a defaulter.

anchor.surface_text: and so, he could not be permitted to enforce his remedy against the sureties. Since on the question of default, we have come to a contrary conclusion,

facts.text: Surety bond executed by respondents Nos. 2 and 3 on 29th September 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The surety bond was executed on the 29th Sept. 1935.

facts.text: Surety bond executed in favour of the court.

anchor.surface_text: This bond was executed in the favour of the court.

facts.text: Clause 5 of surety bond provided sureties would pay if High Court order in C.M.A. No. 362/1929 reversed or varied by Privy Council resulting in respondent No. 1 liable for restitution to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 of the surety bond which is relevant provides that the sureties covenant that if the order of the High Court in C. M. A. No. 362/1929 be reversed or varied by the Privy Council and as a result of the said variation or reversal respondent No. 1 becomes liable to pay by way of restitution any amount to the said appellant in the Privy Council, the sureties would pay whatever sum may become payable by the said respondent

facts.text: Privy Council decision remitted matter to trial court for ascertaining amount due to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that as a result of the decision of the Privy Council, the matter was remitted to the trial Court for ascertaining the amount due to the appellant

facts.text: Compromise decree passed between appellant and respondent No. 1 during pendency of appeals in Madras High Court against trial court decision on remanded proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: and it was during the pendency of the appeals which were pending in the Madras High Court against the decision of the trial Court on the applications made by the respective parties in the remanded proceedings that the compromise decree was passed between the appellant and respondent No. 1

facts.text: Compromise decree introduced complicated provisions for satisfaction of appellant's claim, including possession of properties and adjustment of rival claims.

anchor.surface_text: The compromise decree has introduced complicated provisions for the satisfaction of the appellants claim against respondent No. 1. Under the compromise decree, the appellant would have been entitled to take possession of the properties in suit and in that process, rival claims of both the parties would have been adjusted.

facts.text: Compromise decree gave time to respondent No. 1 and was not executable immediately.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it is clear that the compromise agreement gave time to respondent No. 1 and the decree was, therefore, not executable immediately after it was passed.

facts.text: Compromise decree settled disputes including respondent No. 1's claim for damages against appellant for creating occupancy rights in favour of strangers as mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that amongst the disputes which were settled between the parties was included the claim made by respondent No. 1 for damages on account of the fact that the appellant had created occupancy rights in favour of strangers in respect of the properties which were in his possession as a mortgagee.

facts.text: Damages claim by respondent No. 1 was outside proceedings contemplated by Privy Council order.

anchor.surface_text: This claim is plainly outside the proceedings contemplated and permitted by the order passed by the Privy Council,

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant cannot seek remedy against sureties respondents Nos. 2 and 3 despite not being defaulter.

anchor.surface_text: and yet this dispute has been settled by the compromise decree which means that a matter which was strictly not germane to the judicial proceedings in which the surety bond was executed has been introduced by the parties in their final settlement. Therefore, we are satisfied that though the appellant succeeds in showing that he was not a defaulter, he cannot seek his remedy against the surety, respondents Nos. 2 and 3.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 2 and 3 did not raise discharge point in trial court but raised it in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that respondents No. 2 and 3 did not take any such contention in the trial Court, but that may be because parties had then concentrated on the issue as to who was the defaulter. But when the appeals were argued before the High Court, this point was specifically urged by respondent No. 2

facts.text: High Court considered the point raised by respondent No. 2 regarding discharge of sureties.

anchor.surface_text: and it has been considered by the High Court.

facts.text: At time of surety bond execution, dispute was money dispute expected to result in specified payment order.

anchor.surface_text: At the time when the surety bond was executed, the dispute pending between the parties was the money dispute the decision of which would have ended in an order directing one party to pay another a certain specified amount.

In support of this argument, reliance is placed on the equitable principles underlying section 135 of the Indian Contract Act. Mr. Kuppuswamy contests this position and urges that s. 135 is inapplicable to a surety bond executed in favour of a court and he argues that appellants remedy against the surety is not affected by the fact that the dispute between the appellant and respondent No. 1 was amicably settled and terminated in a compromise decree.

concepts.interpretation: Provision does not apply in terms to surety bonds executed in favour of the court as they do not constitute a contract of guarantee under s.126 involving creditor, principal debtor and surety; however, the equitable principles underlying it apply equally to court surety bonds.

The argument is that if the point had been raised in the Court of first instance, the appellant would have shown that respondents Nos. 2 and 3 had consented to the compromise agreement between the appellant and respondent No. 1.

issues.text: whether the appellant is entitled to seek his remedy against the surety

anchor.surface_text: In determining this question, it is necessary first to enquire into the nature and extent of the liability undertaken by respondents Nos. 2 and 3 in executing the surety bond. The surety bond was executed on the 29th Sept. 1935. Clause 5 of the surety bond which is relevant provides that the sureties covenant that if the order of the High Court in C. M. A. No. 362/1929 be reversed or varied by the Privy Council and as a result of the said variation or reversal respondent No. 1 becomes liable to pay by way of restitution any amount to the said appellant in the Privy Council, the sureties would pay whatever sum may become payable by the said respondent and that if they failed therein, then any sum payable shall be realised in the man- ner specified in the said clause.

issues.text: whether s. 135 of the Indian Contract Act or principles underlying it apply to surety bonds executed in favour of the court

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument, reliance is placed on the equitable principles underlying section 135 of the Indian Contract Act. Mr. Kuppuswamy contests this position and urges that s. 135 is inapplicable to a surety bond executed in favour of a court and he argues that appellants remedy against the surety is not affected by the fact that the dispute between the appellant and respondent No. 1 was amicably settled and terminated in a compromise decree. This controversy raises the question as to whether s. 135 of the Indian Contract Act or principles underlying it apply to surety bonds executed in favour of the court.

issues.text: it is only if the amount claimed by appellant from respondent No. 1 can be said to be the result of the reversal or variation by the Privy Council of the orders under appeal before it that the surety bond can be proceeded against

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, Mr. Sastri for the surety agrees that the surety bond must be strictly construed and it is only if the amount claimed by appellant from respondent No. 1 can be said to be the result of the reversal or variation by the Privy Council of the orders under appeal before it that the surety bond can be proceeded against. Mr. Sastri urges that when disputes were pending between the appellant and respondent No. 1 before the Madras High Court, the parties compromised the disputes and the compromise decree which followed acts as a discharge of the liability of the sureties.

issues.text: whether liability under such a surety bond is discharged by reason of the fact that a compromise decree had been passed in the judicial proceedings in which the surety bond came to be executed

anchor.surface_text: In determining the question as to whether liability under such a surety bond is discharged by reason of the fact that a compromise decree had been passed in the judicial proceedings in which the surety bond came to be executed, it will always be necessary to examine the terms of the bond itself.

issues.text: Did the surety contemplate when he executed the bond that the dispute pending between the debtor and the creditor may be compromised, or did he contemplate that the dispute would, and must be settled by the court and not compromised by the parties?

anchor.surface_text: Did the surety contemplate when he executed the bond that the dispute pending between the debtor and the creditor may be compromised, or did he contemplate that the dispute would, and must be settled by the court and not compromised by the parties? If the terms of the bond indicate that the surety undertook the liability on the basis that the dispute would be decided on the merits by the court in invitum and would not be amicably settled, then the compromise of the dispute would discharge the liability of the surety  vide The Official Liquidators, The Travancore National Quilon Bank Ltd. v. The Official Assignee of Madras,

arguments.claim: the provisions of s. 135 cannot apply to a court bond... equitable principles underlying the provisions of s. 135 apply to such a bond... extension of time granted by the creditor to the debtor should discharge the surety even where the surety bond is executed in favour of the court

anchor.surface_text: This controversy raises the question as to whether s. 135 of the Indian Contract Act or principles underlying it apply to surety bonds executed in favour of the court. Section 135 provides that a contract between the creditor and the principal debtor, by which the creditor makes a composition with or promises to give time to, or not to sue, the principal debtor discharges the surety, unless the surety assents to such contract.

anchor.surface_text: An attempt was made by Mr. Kuppuswamy to suggest that respondents Nos. 2 and 3 should not have been allowed to raise this point before the High Court, because no such point had been taken by them in the trial Court. We do not think there is any substance in this argument.

holdings.text: though the appellant succeeds in showing that he was not a defaulter, he cannot seek his remedy against the surety, respondents Nos. 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: and yet this dispute has been settled by the compromise decree which means that a matter which was strictly not germane to the judicial proceedings in which the surety bond was executed has been introduced by the parties in their final settlement. Therefore, we are satisfied that though the appellant succeeds in showing that he was not a defaulter, he cannot seek his remedy against the surety, respondents Nos. 2 and 3.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compromise decree introduced complicated provisions, gave time to respondent No. 1, and settled extraneous damages claim outside Privy Council order and bond contemplation.

holdings.text: in terms, the provisions of s. 135 cannot apply to a court bond.

anchor.surface_text: Such a bond is given to the court and not to the creditor and it is in the discretion of the court to enforce the bond or not. Therefore, there cannot be any doubt that in terms, the provisions of s. 135 cannot apply to a court bond.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court surety bond lacks creditor-principal debtor-surety structure required by s. 126 of Contract Act.

holdings.text: the equitable principles underlying the provisions of s. 135 apply to such a bond.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there cannot be any doubt that in terms, the provisions of s. 135 cannot apply to a court bond. It is also clear that the equitable principles underlying the provisions of s. 135 apply to such a bond.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equitable rules like discharge for giving time apply equally to court bonds as to ordinary guarantees.

holdings.text: the extension of time granted by the creditor to the debtor should not discharge the surety even where the surety bond is executed in favour of the court.

anchor.surface_text: If, for instance, the decree-holder gives time to the judgment-debtor and promises not to seek his remedy against him during that period, there is no reason why the extension of time granted by the creditor to the debtor should not discharge the surety even where the surety bond is executed in favour of the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Surety entitled to require creditor to pursue principal debtor; time extension without assent affects this right.

holdings.text: If the terms of the bond indicate that the surety undertook the liability on the basis that the dispute would be decided on the merits by the court in invitum and would not be amicably settled, then the compromise of the dispute would discharge the liability of the surety.

anchor.surface_text: In determining the question as to whether liability under such a surety bond is discharged by reason of the fact that a compromise decree had been passed in the judicial proceedings in which the surety bond came to be executed, it will always be necessary to examine the terms of the bond itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of bond terms determines if surety contemplated amicable settlement or only adversarial court decision; supported by precedents.

holdings.text: it is impossible to hold that it was within the contemplation of the sureties when they executed the bond that the parties would amicably settle their dispute in the manner they have done.

anchor.surface_text: At the time when the surety bond was executed, the dispute pending between the parties was the money dispute the decision of which would have ended in an order directing one party to pay another a certain specified amount. The compromise decree has introduced complicated provisions for the satisfaction of the appellants claim against respondent No. 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bond contemplated simple money payment post-reversal; compromise involved property possession, rival claims adjustment, time extension, extraneous damages.

holdings.text: We do not think there is any substance in this argument [that respondents Nos. 2 and 3 should not have been allowed to raise this point before the High Court].

anchor.surface_text: An attempt was made by Mr. Kuppuswamy to suggest that respondents Nos. 2 and 3 should not have been allowed to raise this point before the High Court, because no such point had been taken by them in the trial Court. We do not think there is any substance in this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point specifically urged and considered by High Court; focus in trial was on default issue.

holdings.text: on the question of default, we have come to a contrary conclusion [to High Court that appellant was defaulter].

anchor.surface_text: and so, he could not be permitted to enforce his remedy against the sureties. Since on the question of default, we have come to a contrary conclusion,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrary to High Court's basis for rejecting claim.
